item.title: Comparing Low-Code Tools as a Developer
item.description: When first hearing of the concept of “no-code” I have to admit I cringed a bit. The implication that a mere mortal client could combine services without ever getting a dev involved seemed cute and definitely wouldn’t lead to anything genuinely valuable. I come from the age of Hackathons, where a devs would quickly put together really interesting combinations of services in the blink of an eye. They would do all this for nothing more than the joy of building, rather than the offer of expensive prizes from some well funded business as a form of motivation.

item.title: A Tale of Two Copies
item.description: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times. That's when I hit a performance mystery that sent me down a multi-day rabbit hole of adventure.
